Title:
Deep Sequencing Allowed the Completion of the Genome of
Grapevine Red Globe Virus and Evidenced Recurring Co-Infection with
Other Tymoviruses in Grapevine.
Abstract:
The complete genome sequences of three isolates of
Grapevine red globe virus were determined by combining deep and
conventional sequencing. The analysis of the viral genomes supported the
adscription of the virus to the genus Maculavirus. Also, the comparison
of the genetic distances along the GRGV genomes was consistent with the
identification of functional domains and significant genomic regions.
The virus was identified in other grapevine clones and RNA-seq of total
or small RNAs allowed the identification of other viruses simultaneously
present in the plants. The number of sequence reads matching to the
different virus genomes was used as a quantitative estimation of the
relative virus titers. The availability of several GRGV genome sequences
combined to the ones obtained in this work allowed designing consensus
primers that were used to detect GRGV in different grapevine clones. The
profile of vsiRNAs distribution along the GRGV genomes suggested the
presence of subgenomic RNAs. The 21-nt class of vsiRNAs displayed a
major representation as described previously in the grapevine. In
contradiction with a previous report, we found that the positive sense
vsiRNAs matching to the GRGV genome were predominant over the negative
ones. Co-infection of GRGV and GRVFV is apparently common and the
significance of the presence of these viruses in the grapevine is
discussed.
